text:
GEOFFREY WILSON: Thanks for
exploring teaching and learning

materials from
MIT Open Learning.

We often make use of
openly licensed materials

to ensure that
people like you have

an access to high quality,
modifiable resources

for your own
educational initiatives.
My name is Geoff Wilson.

And I'm an Intellectual Property
Manager here at Open Learning.

In this video,
I'll be guiding you

through a few ways we identify
openly licensed materials.

My hope is that you'll
be able to apply

some of these strategies
in your own work.

Before we go on, just
a brief disclaimer--
I am not a US attorney.

And this video does not
contain any legal advice.

Before open licensing,
the only way

to share copyrighted material
was through a direct license
or a claim of fair use.

However, now, we
also have the ability

to share materials through
a standard open license.

To understand the
benefits of open licenses,

we're going to contrast that
with traditional copyrighted
materials.
So what is copyright?

US Copyright Law
grants protection

over certain types of
intellectual property,

namely expressive works
of original authorship,

such as books, songs,
photos, and movie scripts.

US Copyright Law creates
a limited exclusive right

over the protected property,
which allows the copyright

holder to control publishing,
copying, distribution,
and derivative uses of the work.

Even for educational and
non-commercial purposes,

reuse of all rights reserved
or copyrighted content
presents challenges.

On the one hand, a
claim of fair use

requires thorough evaluation
and documentation, basically
a justification.

And even then, a
copyright holder

may demand that the
content be taken down.

Third party license
agreements, on the other hand,

can be time consuming
and expensive.

But now, what is
an open license?

Simply put, it's a content
license that grants permission

to access, reuse, and
redistribute a work
with few or no restrictions.

Open licenses are an alternative
to traditional copyright

protection, as denoted by
the copyright C symbol,
or all rights reserved R symbol.

When it comes to open licenses,
there are standard ones,

like those provided
by Creative Commons.

And there are also many custom
or website-specific licenses
out there.

At MIT Open Learning,
we recommend

using open license
resources because they're

generally less restrictive than
standard copyright protection.
They're also less confusing.

The rights and permissions tend
to be more explicitly defined,

whereas a claim of fair
use is inherently more

uncertain and subjective until
a judge makes a specific ruling.

Now, there are two popular
types of open content--

Creative Commons open
licensing and open access.

But before we explain
what those are,

I want to highlight two other
alternatives or exceptions
to copyright law.

The first is the
public domain, which

refers to all expressive
works that are not protected
by any right of copyright.

The second is fair use,
which I've already mentioned.

Fair use is an exception to
exclusive rights of copyright.

While copyright owners may enjoy
exclusive rights over their IP,

US law stipulates that those
exclusive rights are not
absolute.

Fair use is a carve-out of
those exclusive rights, which

allows use of copyrighted
works for certain purposes

such as research,
teaching, criticism, parody

without permission from
the copyright holder.

Now, let's get back
to open content.

The Creative Commons is a
set of standardized copyright

licenses, which was
conceived as an alternative

to traditional all rights
reserved copyright.

Part of what makes
them so useful

is how straightforward
the licenses are.

Each element of a license is
explicitly defined so that both

authors and users understand
what can and cannot be done
with a given work.

On the chart, the
licenses go from least

restrictive at the top to most
restrictive at the bottom.

The first license is shown
as CC BY, where BY simply

means that a work can
be copied or distributed

in any form or fashion, so
long as the original author is
credited.

Going down the list,
certain other CC

licenses stipulate
further restrictions,

such as no commercial use,
or NC, or no derivative use,
such as ND.

With the Creative Commons
symbols, what you see
is what you get.

Here is a great
Creative Commons example

from an MIT political
science course that's
available on OpenCourseWare.

The course homepage
image shows a photo
of the US Capitol building.

Looking at the
attribution, we can

see that not only did the course
team do a great job of properly

attributing the
source image, but we

can see that they have complied
with the CC BY NC license

that the photographer
stipulated.

Millions of photos and
other multimedia resources

are made available online
via CC and other licenses.

Here is a full-size
version of the image.

Another benefit of
Creative Commons

is that it allows users
to find their way back
to the original source material.

The term open access is specific
to peer-reviewed research.

And it comes from a movement to
make research literature more
accessible.

Traditional academic journals
involve exclusive rights

and subscription fees, which can
be a barrier to open science.

Here's one example from a
molecular biology class that's
available on the EdX platform.

On the left is a frame
from the video lecture

showing the professor
incorporating material

from an open access journal
article into their lecture.

On the right is the original
figure from the journal article
itself.

As you can see,
the article itself

is copyrighted with all rights
reserved by the authors.

However, they saw fit to
make their work openly

accessible with a
Creative Commons license.

The public domain
refers to works

that are not subject to
any copyrights whatsoever.

This means that
such works can be

used by anyone for any purpose
without the owner or author's
permission.

A work can enter the public
domain for several reasons.
Its copyright has expired.

The creator waived their
rights of copyright

and placed their work
into the public domain.

And certain works created by or
for the US Federal government

and released to the public
are considered public domain
by default.
One thing to note--

entering the public
domain is permanent.

Works cannot be clawed back from
the public domain once rights

have been waived or after
expiration of copyright.

Here's a colorful
public domain resource

example taken from
a fluid dynamics
course on OpenCourseWare.

The image in question comes
from the US Naval Research
Laboratory.

While attribution
is not required,

it's good etiquette
and a best practice,

as exemplified in the
caption below the figure.

Here, we see the
figure blown up.
This is a global weather chart.

The federal government conducts
a lot of scientific research
and observation.

So it's a great place
to find content to pair
with your teaching materials.

Here is just a handful
of the myriad sites

on the internet that offer
up open license, open access,
and/or public domain multimedia.

These are all resources that we
frequently recommend to the MIT
course teams that we work with.

Thank you for viewing
this presentation.

We at MIT Open Learning hope
that it provides a window

to how and where
open resources are

available to be used with
your new educational projects.
